titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Law Library (University of Michigan)
Records, 1859-2006
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
Michigan Historical Collections Staff

did.abstract: The Law Library was established as part of the University of Michigan Law School in 1859 and is currently maintained and administered as a part of the instructional and research operation of the Law School. The collection contains documentation related to administrative matters within the Law Library, including financial documentation, correspondence, director files, and documentation on the building expansion of the library. The collection also contains some of the material removed from the collections at the library, as well as documentation related to the Law School, which was also previously housed in the library collections.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: The record group (donor no. 1667) was transferred to the Bentley Library in November 1982. Subsequent small accessions were received in 1984, 1990 and 1999.

accessrestrict.p: The records are open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

processinfo.p: The records were processed by Darwin C. Matthews, January 1983 Thomas E. Powers, 1984 (collected documents) Kristine Palmquist, 1999 Heather Briston, October 1999 Erin Passehl, February 2006 Hannah Gulick, June 2014

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Law Library (University of Michigan) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Law School of the University of Michigan was founded in October 1859. Earlier in April of the same year, the Regents appropriated $2,000 for the establishment of a law library. In addition, in October 1859, Judge Thomas M. Cooley of Detroit donated 350 volumes to the library. These volumes formed the basis of the library's collection. During the 19th century the Law Library received three major gifts; one from Judge Richard Fletcher of Boston in 1866 of 800 volumes, and two others from Detroit businessman Christian H. Buhl. In 1886 Buhl donated his personal library of over 5,000 volumes to the Law Library. This increased the size of the collection to nearly 10,000 volumes. In 1894 Buhl gave the library $10,000. With this bequest the library was able to increase substantially the scope of its collection. In 1929, William Cook, a beneficiary of the Law School, donated his entire personal collection to the library, and had the room in which his collection had been housed reconstructed in the library to house the material there.

Originally the collection consisted mainly of reports from Michigan, Pennsylvania, New York, and some New England states. The early focus of the library's collection was judicial decisions rather than acts of legislatures. However, in 1886, the library began a campaign to obtain statutes from all states in the Union. The money received from the Buhl bequest also helped the library to purchase and develop a section on foreign law. Up to that time the library held volumes relating only to American and English law. Throughout the early 20th century, acquisition of materials concerning foreign law and international law gave the library one of the best collections in the United States.

The first three law librarians, Isaac Marston, Levi L. Barbour, and William R. Day, were all students in the Law School. Joseph H. Vance served as the first full-time librarian from 1883 to 1899. In 1899, Judge Victor Lane became the law librarian and presided over a collection of roughly 18,000 volumes. He did not oversee the administrative duties of the library, but rather concentrated on teaching, research, and collection development. The day-to-day activities of the library were the responsibilities of his assistant librarians: Gertrude Woodard (1901-1915), Elizabeth Steere (1915-1918), Blanche Harroun (1918-1924), and Rebecca Wilson (1924-1927). These women, led by Woodard, brought the collection under organizational control through the use of modern library principles and practices. Professor Hobart R. Coffey succeeded Judge Lane as law librarian, a position he held from 1926 to 1966. By 1937 the library contained 133,000 volumes. Professor Coffey's assistant librarian, Esther Betz, worked at the library from 1927 to 1963. Professor Beverly Pooley became the law librarian in 1965, a position he held until 1985. From 1985 until 1995 Pooley served as associate dean of the Law Library. Margaret Leary became director of the library in 1985. In 2011 Barbara H. Garavaglia moved from assistant director to full director of the Law Library.

The Law Library was first located in the south wing of University Hall and then moved to the Law Building in 1863. The library moved to its present location, the William W. Cook Legal Research Building, in 1931. After much debate, the library underwent major renovation in 1980 to expand into the area underneath the Legal Research Building. The award-winning underground addition to the Law Library was designed by architect Gunnar Birkerts. In 1986 the library was officially designated as the Allen F. and Alene Smith Law Library.

The Law Library's purpose is to build collections and provide services to support the teaching and research needs of Law School faculty and students. The Law Library's collections, services, and policies are primarily designed to benefit the Law School's faculty and students, and others officially connected with the Law School. The Law Library's secondary users are other University of Michigan faculty and students who have legitimate need to use the collection, and attorneys. As of 2013, the Law Library held 1,044,561 total volumes in both paper and microform format. Current information on the Law Library is available at the following URL: http://www.law.umich.edu/library/
For more information on the Law School, researchers are advised to examine the Law School record group also housed at the Bentley Historical Library.

scopecontent.p: The material included in the Law Library records are primarily the files of the library directors and of Professor Hobart R. Coffey and Esther Betz. The material included in the Law Library records are divided into five series: Administration, Collections, Law School, Audio Visual Material, and William Cook Papers.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Cooperative societies--Michigan--Ann Arbor.
Law.
Libraries--Michigan--Ann Arbor.
controlaccess.corpname: Michigan Wolverine Student Cooperative (University of Michigan)

scopecontent.p: The Administration series contains documents and records relating directly to the operation of the Law Library. Contained within are ten subseries.

The Director's Files concern the administration of the library. There are also topical files created by Professor Coffey relating mainly to his own personal activities. Specific areas of strength within the Director's Files include the Michigan Wolverine Student Cooperative, the Legal Microfilms Association, Professor Coffey's South American Research Tour, and minutes of the Law Library Committee.

did.unittitle: Committee on cooperation with Latin American Libraries

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence Files contain correspondence of Professor Coffey, various library directors from 1962 to 1990, and Esther Betz. Professor Coffey's correspondence is broken down chronologically then alphabetically. These have been retained in the order maintained by Professor Coffey. Correspondence of miscellaneous directors follows the original alphabetical arrangement. Esther Betz's correspondences are organized chronologically. The correspondence files that were added in box 14 are organized alphabetically, per the original order.

The History subseries includes reports and a listing of Regents Proceedings pertinent to the development of the Law Library from 1858 through 1934, proceedings of the Library Committee, and miscellaneous statistics and reports.

did.unittitle: List of Current Foreign Legal Periodicals Received

scopecontent.p: The Library Administration Materials contains information related to changes in the library field, such as the introduction to the Anglo-American Cataloging Rules II and the RLG Serials Project, and how the Law Library reacted. This subseries also contains background information and files from the Library Advisory Committee, overarching objectives, evaluation, and planning by the Law Library, and materials related to a bibliography of Festschriften (homage publications), compiled by Lily Roberts. Also found in this subseries are files on gifts received by the Law Library from 1958-1980, and by two individuals in particular: John Star Hunt and Virginia Earl.

The Library Building Addition subseries includes documents related to the major renovation that occurred in 1980. Of particular importance is the debate whether or not to construct the new library underground. In addition to the manuscript materials is one folder of architectural drawings. The drawings relate to proposals from various architects for the library building addition. The drawings include exterior elevations, plot plans, and renderings of interiors. Additional material on the design of the award-winning underground addition to the library may be found in the records of Gunnar Birkerts and Associates. Birkerts designed the addition and the records of his architectural firm are held at the Bentley Library.

The bulk of the Library Building Addition files were added in 2006. These files include Building Committee Files which contain all materials related to the library addition, including correspondence between library administration and the architect, Gunnar Birkerts and Associates, as well as questionnaires, reports, and sketches of proposed additions to the law library. This collection also houses newspaper clippings and published articles related to the University of Michigan's project, compared to other academic library additions being built during this same period. The Student Building Committee is also represented in this collection.

did.unittitle: Architectural drawings and renderings of proposals for an addition to the law library building, ca. 1960s
Newspaper Articles Relevant to Library Building Addition
Publications Related to Academic Library Additions/Construction in the United States
Published Material Relevant to Library Buildings

scopecontent.p: The Acquisitions subseries contains documents related to the various material that the library would attempt to procure for its collections. This includes primarily correspondence with other institutes because the library was interested in purchasing materials, confirming or cancelling a subscription, or because the library was attempting to complete collections of documents or magazines that were only partially held at the library.

did.unittitle: Islamic and South Asia Material PL. 480

scopecontent.p: The Construction subseries contains material that is separate from the main library addition that was constructed in 1980. This subseries includes records related to the construction of the Rare Book Room and the Computer-Assisted Research Room, as well as a staff Tea Room.

did.unittitle: Law School Expansion Final Report, Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates

scopecontent.p: The Depository subseries is made up of general information about the library depository and the records of the inspections of the depository.
The Financial subseries contains primarily budget files, as well as records on the five-year projection and salary funds.

The Policies and Procedures contain manuals and instructions related to the acquiring and maintenance of the material in the Law Library. This includes procedural manuals and collection strategy manuals.
The Topical subseries contains documents from the advisory committee, annual reports, blueprints, information on the microform and looseleaf services at the library, and other various documents.

did.unittitle: Government Printing Office Conversion to Fiche
Move of Reference Services and Collection

scopecontent.p: The Collections series is made up of material that was previously held at the Law Library in their collections but was then removed and donated to the Bentley Historical Library. This includes various documents, such as Law School publications, and notes on various lectures that were given at the university by James Campbell and James B. Angell. Significant material on the Michigan Law Review is contained here, including founding documents, article of associations, minutes, and a history file containing correspondence from several notable figures. Correspondents include Supreme Court justices Louis Brandeis, James Byrnes, and Harlan Stone as well as Attorney General Francis Biddle, Senator Arthur Vandenberg, and alumnus John D. Voelker.

Within this is a subseries of Collected Late 18th and 19th Century Documents. In 1984, the law library added these documents to their holdings at the Bentley, which it had received from various sources, mainly former faculty and alumni. Included are various legal instruments, certificates of indenture, commissions, and appointments. There is also a register of cases prepared by law student Dwight May, and a volume of a law periodical kept by Albert J. Chapman. Many of the documents are oversize.

did.unittitle: William Cook document introducing John B. Trevor

scopecontent.p: The Audio Visual series includes photographs, slides, cassette tapes, and audio reels. The photograph section includes those taken of the construction of the new building on January 10, 1980 and outsize mounted photographs taken by Balthazar Korab of proposed models of the new building. The slides consist of around 250 slides of alternative schemes for the law school additions, and details of the law school, proposed library additions, and the built addition.

In 1990, sound recordings of the Thomas M. Cooley, William W. Bishop, and William W. Cook Lectures were added to the Law Library's records. Additional records of these lectures, including correspondence pertaining to arrangements along with programs and printed copies of the presentation may be found in the University of Michigan Law School records also held by the Bentley.

A second set of audio-visual material was added to the collection in 2014. This includes glass plate slides of the library and the law school buildings, and negatives of individuals collected from a number of sources, among them secondary sources. Cassette tapes are also included which have the recordings of various lectures, including from the Cook and Cooley lecture series' and from lectures given by James White. Also included are audio reel-to-reel tapes that contain recordings of presentations at conferences, including the Institute on Advocacy and the Institute on Improving the Method of Judicial Selection in Michigan.

scopecontent.p: The William Cook Papers series is primarily related to Cook's book American Institutions and Their Preservation. This is divided into its own subseries and contains correspondence, notes, memos, and early drafts of the document. At the end of the series is a file entitled "The Composite American and His Mission," which was the early title of this book. The series also contains other articles, correspondence, miscellaneous writings, and memos.

did.unittitle: Extracts from Census Reports and World Almanacs
Sheets Subsequent to Completion of 1st Edition
Article -- "Power and Responsibility of the American Bar"
"The Composite American and His Mission" Newspaper Clippings

scopecontent.p: The Law School series contains documents that were donated to the Law Library but were related to the Law School rather than a particular aspect of the library. This includes announcements, flyers, directories, scrapbooks (located in outsize material), and two subseries. The Michigan Law Review subseries includes chronological issues, lists of authors, and meeting minutes. The second subseries contains information on the Lawyer's Club, a group of students within the Law School that is centered around the exclusive housing within the Law Quadrangle. The Lawyer's Club's files contain documentation including blueprints for the building, publications, rules of housing, and a series of student notebooks from alumnus Allan Rubin.

did.unittitle: History ("The Drama in the Evolution of the Lawyers Club and the Michigan Law Quadrangle" by Olga M. Overn and The Story of William W. Cook's Gift)
